content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle for Clash of Code, fair rules, and fun to implement

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool little string manipulation puzzle. The overlapping substring counting adds a nice twist can't just use simple string.count(). Good mix of rules that build on each other without being overcomplicated.
not supposed to know the syllables by heart. It would be really helpful if you could display the syllables

I think this is quite a clear and interesting clash :) Just wondering if you've tried code golfing your own solution? It took me >15 minutes to get mine somewhat golfed, although 189 characters is still quite sizeable.

s=input();v="aeiou"
f=lambda t:sum(s[i:i+len(t)]==t for i in range(len(s)))
print(max(sum(map(s.count,v))-f("oo")-f("oa")-f("au")-f("iou")-(s[-1]=="e")+(s[-2:]=="le"and s[-3] not in v),1))

(to be fair, I had mistakenly thought the Python count() function for strings would help count overlapping instances)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is unique test of a coder's ability to identify substrings in a string and the instructions are clear and unambiguous.

SInce none of the strings will have spaces, the stub generator can be:
read s:word(500)
instead.

Goal
* Please format "a", "e", "i", "o", "u", "oo", "oa", "au", "iou" and "le" as {{constants}}.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. write answer.

Cases
* Each test and its validator should cover the same scenario with similar inputs and outputs, and cases are ordered in increasing complexity. Please revise the cases as follows:

  - Test 1 and Validator 1: Only Rule 1 is needed.

  - Test 2 and Validator 2: Only Rules 1 and 2 are needed. No overlapping of substrings.

  - Test 3 and Validator 3: Only Rules 1 and 2 are needed. With overlapping of substrings.

  - Test 4 and Validator 4: Only Rules 1 to 3 are needed. [[s]] ends with "e" but not "le".

  - Test 5 and Validator 5: Rules 1 to 4 are needed. [[s]] ends with "le" and the character before it is not a vowel.

  - Test 6 and Validator 6: Rules 1 to 4 are needed. [[s]] ends with "le" and the character before it is a vowel.

  - Test 7 and Validator 7: Rule 5 is needed.

  - (up to Pair 7, the lenght of [[s]] is between 3 and 50.)

  - Test 8 and Validator 8: Most rules are needed, and the length of [[s]] is between 50 and 100.

  - Test 9 and Validator 9: Most rules are needed, and the length of [[s]] is between 100 and 500.

Thanks.

thanks :)
i'll try to make it like that
You don't have to know anything about syllables. The Goal section explains how they should be identified and counted.
also i wanna ask more about the stub generator since i don't really understand what you said lol

Great improvements there! A few more fixes should do it.

Goal
* Please remove all the quotation marks (both single and double ones).

Cases
* Validator 8: Please revise [[s]] to be more similar to Test 8.

* Please add a new pair of cases where all the conditions below hold:
  â€¢ 450 â‰¤ Length of [[s]] â‰¤ 500
  â€¢ [[s]] includes all single vowels and all substring vowels. Both overlapping substrings and non-overlapping substrings should be included.
  â€¢ [[s]] ends with "ule".
  â€¢ [[s]] contains all letters of the English alphabet (a to z) in a *random* order.

Thanks.

P.S. You updated the stub generator correctly. In case you're confused, check how the default code generated differs when the stub contains "write answer" and when it's without that line.
fixed case 8 to be more similar to each other (while also checking the "oooooo..." case)
I can't see any changes yet. Is it still being saved?

it's saved now, should be showed up the test 10
anything else?
Looks fine to me. Thank you. ðŸ™‚
